Literature Review: Pleiotropy, a phenomenon where a single gene or mutation affects multiple phenotypic traits, has been a long-standing concept in genetics. The advent of functional genomics has enabled researchers to quantify pleiotropy for a large fraction of genes in a genome, revealing the extent of this phenomenon. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of pleiotropy, its molecular basis, and the evolutionary consequences of this phenomenon. We will discuss the L-shaped distribution of pleiotropy, the cost of complexity, regulatory versus coding evolution, environmental pleiotropy and adaptation, and the evolution of ageing and other seemingly harmful traits. Our analysis will be grounded in empirical data and theoretical frameworks, highlighting the complex relationships between pleiotropy, evolution, and disease.
